title: Wilde Rambler
text:
“So in my lineage, as I progressed through the industry, we had the Space Horse, then we had the Cosmic Stallion, and then I created the Earth ship, which was an iter iteration of those works, an evolution of those works. And now we have the Rambler. And so when I, things I like in gravel bikes. I believe that an endurance bike comfortable is fast.”
– Jeff Frane, Gravel Ride Podcast

title: Gravel 2D
text:
Tip




Hover over data for model and frame size identification.
Scroll legend and click on items to identify specific model and frame size combinations.
Click on Focal checkbox to view only the frame size used for the classification.
Click on popup icon-bar over legend to zoom in/out and pan.









Note



Classification of gravel bikes is based on a frame size that fits a 176 cm (5’ 9.3”) high rider, according to manufacturer’s charts.


Click here to see a version of this page that simulataneously highlights all frame sizes within a model

title: Gravel Ternary
text:
Tip




Hover over data for model and frame size identification.
Scroll legend and click on items to identify specific model in the plot.
Click on popup icon-bar over legend to zoom in/out and pan.









Note




The ternary scores are the projections of the centered, scaled data onto the style (Racy, Relaxed, Rowdy) axes.
Each style axes was constructed as the multivariate axis from the centroid to the style mean of the centered, scaled data.
The input data is the ML subset of bikes that fit a 176 cm rider

title: What is Gravel Style?
text:
It’s common to read from company websites or from bike influencers on YouTube that gravel bikes come in two flavors: race and off-road. 2D scatter plots suggest three classes:

Racy. Effectively, these have cyclocross bike geometry
Relaxed. Compared to Racy: More upright, longer rearends, and longer trail – this is the direction of endurance road bikes compared to race road bikes.
Rowdy. Compared to Racy: Longer, slacker front ends, and steeper seat tubes – this is the direction of XC mountain bikes compared to road bikes.







Note



Classification of gravel bikes is based on a frame size that fits a 176 cm (5’ 9.3”) high rider, according to manufacturer’s charts.

title: Gravel Bike Geometry Project
text:
The Gravel 2D page contains interactive, 2D scatter plots of different pairs of frame geometry measures for all gravel bike models and frame sizes in the database.









The Gravel Ternary page contains an interactive, ternary plot for all gravel bike models in the database. Each ternary plot axis is a style score (0 – 100) for one of the styles: Racy, Relaxed, and Rowdy.









The What is Gravel Style? page contains interactive, 2D scatter plots of different pairs of frame geometry measures to compare gravel bikes in the database to Road Race, Road Endurance, Cyclocross, and XC Mountain bikes.









The Gravel Tree page contains a tree diagram showing the relative similarity in frame geometry among all gravel bikes in the database and the clustering of the models into three major styles.









The Gravel Table page contains a table of the classification of all gravel bike models in the database into All-road, Endurance, and Trail categories.









Also, check out the Gravel Stories
Which gravel bikes have mountain bike inspired geometry?
Is a gravel bike a 1990s mountain bike?
